thread.title: Google and Verizon spent $27 million in a week advertising the Pixel phone
thread.title_full: Google and Verizon spent $27 million in a week advertising the Pixel phone

posts.title: Google and Verizon spent $27 million in a week advertising the Pixel phone
posts.text:
Google and Verizon spent $27 million in a week advertising the Pixel phone View more By Ric Cowley , News Editor 
Google and mobile carrier Verizon have spent a combined $27 million advertising the Pixel line of phones since it launched. 
This is according to a report from Wave7 Research, which studied Pixel phone sales and advertising spend during its first month of launch. 
It found that 7.5% of all phone activations at Verizon stores over the last month were Pixel phones. The phone was initially only available through Verizon in North America, which explains the uptake. 
Big spend 
As well as this, Wave7 found that Google had spent $15 million on TV advertising between October 27th and November 2nd. Verizon spent $12 million on its own Pixel-focused TV ads during the same period. 
The phone is now available from other carriers, though the report notes that these stores are "not a significant factor" in the phone's activation rates. 
Google's Pixel launched on October 20th in five countries. Prices for the phone begin at $649 for the most basic model.

thread.title_full: Verizon offers deep discounts on Pixel phones (as little as $240) and Google Home for Black Friday

posts.author: Michael Crider
posts.title: Verizon offers deep discounts on Pixel phones (as little as $240) and Google Home for Black Friday
posts.text:
Verizon Wireless 
Black Friday deals have been kind of underwhelming for the last few years, but Verizon seems to be taking full advantage of its "exclusive" on the US carrier version of the Pixel phones. For customers who buy a new phone today (Thanksgiving) or tomorrow, the price is reduced to $10 a month for the Pixel and $15 a month for the Pixel XL . That works out to just $239.99 for the Pixel and $359.99 for the Pixel XL (only the 128GB model of the larger phone is being discounted) over the two-year payment period. 
If you're waiting to hear the catch, here it is: this isn't a cash discount. You're actually paying the full retail price of the phone, less a $409 bill credit that's split up month by month. The discount is only for new customers, and you must remain active on Verizon for the full term of the financing period to qualify for the discount. So anyone hoping to snag a dirt-cheap Pixel on Verizon with an initial signup and then head for a cheaper carrier is out of luck. 
Those looking for any other device get a deal that's much less sweet: $100 off the price of any new Android phone $400 or higher for an upgrade, or $200 off for a new customer or a new line. Both of those offers end on Sunday, November 27th. 
There's at least one discount to be had if you're not interested in Verizon's cell phone service. Verizon is selling the Google Home assistant speaker , and just like other retailers , it's offering the gadget for $99.99 ($30 off) for the time being. (It's the same Wi-Fi connected device, of course - the Home has no mobile connection.) If you can't find one elsewhere, a Verizon store or the online storefront might be your last chance. Source:

thread.title: HD Voice problems on iPhone 7
thread.title_full: HD Voice problems on iPhone 7

posts.author: jk870
posts.title: HD Voice problems on iPhone 7
posts.text: Verizon, Siminn, O2 DE, Telia N, Lycamobile DK, Orange FR Feedback Score 0 HD Voice problems on iPhone 7 I have two iPhones: a 7 and a 7+. Advanced calling is enabled on both lines, and both phones are set for Voice+Data LTE. Here's where the fun begins. Outbound calls FROM these two 7's TO other HD voice compatible devices generally connect in HD. But oddly, sometimes these calls are only HD voice one-way. The party receiving the call from the iPhones will hear HD voice (and see the indicator on-screen), but the iPhone side hears standard audio and sees no HD indicator. Inbound calls TO the iPhones, FROM those other compatible devices, will not connect in HD at all. Experience is the same on Wifi calling. I've removed advanced calling from both lines on the account, re-added it, changed settings on the phone, and even did a factory reset on the 7+. Nothing changes at all, and there is no improvement when connected to a different LTE cellsite. I chatted with Verizon, and they were worthless; I get it, the lack of HD voice should not be a showstopper, but I'm a nerd about wideband audio codecs and if the capability exists I want it to work. Plus I want to be able to use the conferencing capabilities. Is anyone else noting advanced calling anomalies with the 7, or is it just me? I'm beginning to suspect that it must be another software issue. Both 7's are up to date.

thread.title: A gift of giving this Thanksgiving | 13wmaz.com
thread.title_full: A gift of giving this Thanksgiving | 13wmaz.com

posts.title: A gift of giving this Thanksgiving | 13wmaz.com
posts.text:
Verizon employee brings Thanksgiving help to Macon woman Verizon employee brings Thanksgiving help to Macon woman Gabrielle Dawkins, WMAZ 6:24 PM. EST November 24, 2016 (Photo: Wade, Jakie) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN GOOGLE+ PINTEREST 
A woman's struggle led her to have a Thanksgiving this year that she didn't get to have last year. 
Gabrielle Dawkins introduces us to the person who went the extra mile after responding to a different issue. 
Nancy Hogan moved to Macon about 10 years ago. She called Verizon on Sunday for assistance on transferring her contacts over to a new phone. 
“I couldn't believe it. I had prayed and prayed that someone could help us,” said Hogan. Nancy Hogan's prayers were answered, by a stranger, an employee at Verizon named Victoria Hay.“She just called and said that she was very upset. She was just saying that she's bedridden and she can't get around the house,” said Hay. Hogan said that her phone fell into some water and that something was wrong with it. 
“I depend on my phone because I have very bad anxiety, depression, and PTSD,” said Hogan. Because Hogan was unable to leave her house, Hay met her there. It turned out that the phone was not usable, so Hay went to buy her a flip phone.“And that's the phone going off right now. That's someone trying to call me,” Hogan said in excitement. Hogan said that with most of her money going toward bills, she didn't have enough money to get a Thanksgiving dinner with her family, but that's where the gift of giving came into play.“Not only did she bring the phone on Monday, she brought us our entire Thanksgiving dinner, which, to me, could only come from prayer,“ said Hogan. 
She gave Hogan a hen, some vegetables, and bread to eat this Thanksgiving.

thread.title: [Deal Alert] Save up to $500 on the Galaxy S7 and S7 edge, LG G5, Moto Z Droid, and more at Best Buy
thread.title_full: [Deal Alert] Save up to $500 on the Galaxy S7 and S7 edge, LG G5, Moto Z Droid, and more at Best Buy

posts.author: Richard Gao
posts.title: [Deal Alert] Save up to $500 on the Galaxy S7 and S7 edge, LG G5, Moto Z Droid, and more at Best Buy
posts.text:
Verizon Wireless 
In the market for a new phone? If you're on AT&T, Sprint, or Verizon, Best Buy may have some deals worth looking at. Some of these offers can get a little confusing between all the different carriers and options, so try to hang on. 
First up, the Galaxy S7 and S7 edge offers. The first one , which includes a free $250 Best Buy gift card, a Gear VR, and $50 in Oculus content, is available to AT&T, Sprint, and Verizon customers who buy and activate an S7 or S7 edge with a monthly installment plan. (The AT&T-exclusive S7 active is also eligible.) That sounds great, until you look at the second one , which comprises of a free $400 Best Buy gift card, the same Gear VR, and the same $50 in Oculus stuff. It's pretty much the same offer, but with an extra $150 for free. However, this superior offer is only available to Verizon customers and new Sprint customers (sorry, AT&T subscribers!). Both offers will expire on November 27th. It's worth noting that you'll only receive the Gear VR after submitting proof of purchase online and waiting a few weeks. 
If you prefer the removable battery and IR blaster-toting LG G5 over the S7 line, AT&T, Sprint, and Verizon customers can get between $100 and $300 in Best Buy gift cards with the purchase and activation of one. Here, AT&T customers are short-changed again; while Sprint and Verizon users get $300 Best Buy gift cards, AT&T people only get $100. It's unclear when this offer will end. 
Want a phone to slice your fruits, vegetables, and meats with instead? The 5.2mm-thin Moto Z Droid may be the phone for you. By you, I mean Verizon customers, as this stunningly slim phone isn't available to purchase at a major discount from any other carrier (yes, I know the unlocked Moto Z exists). From now until November 27th, you can pay just $4.99 a month for 24 months ($119.77 in total) for a phone with a 1440p AMOLED display, a Snapdragon 820, and 4GB of RAM. That price is a whopping $504.23 off the MSRP of $624. Unfortunately, there isn't a similar offer for the superior Z Force. 
Should none of the previous deals have piqued your interest, perhaps this one will: trade any iPhone 6 or 7 variant (except the 6 Plus for some reason), Galaxy S6, Galaxy S6 edge, Galaxy S6 edge+, Galaxy Note 5, LG G5, LG V20, or Droid Turbo in to a Best Buy store (this can't be done online), and get an iPhone 7, iPhone 7 Plus, Pixel, Pixel XL, Galaxy S7, Galaxy S7 edge, Moto Z Droid, Moto Z Droid Force, or LG V20 for free with activation via monthly bill credits. That's quite the incentive. Like many of the other ones previously listed, this offer will cease on the 27th. 
Keep in mind that there are even more deals on carrier phones out there this Black Friday; for instance, the Pixel on Verizon is only $9.99 a month, adding up to $240 over 24 months. You can view them in our roundup of Black Friday/Cyber Monday deals . Source:

thread.title: LG V20 gets official bootloader unlock support ‘for the US open market’
thread.title_full: LG V20 gets official bootloader unlock support ‘for the US open market’

posts.author: Adrian Diaconescu
posts.title: LG V20 gets official bootloader unlock support ‘for the US open market’
posts.text:
Verizon has been selling its network-locked configuration of the successful LG V20 smartphone on a tempting buy-one-get-one-half-off plan for a few weeks now. And T-Mobile’s “kinda crazy” Black Friday deals even include the 5.7-incher as free… under certain conditions.
Meanwhile, the SIM-free, factory unlocked handheld is still rather expensive stateside, at a recommended retail price of $800, which at least covers a number of gifts through B&H, namely a G Pad 7.0 tablet, Asus ZenPower Pro battery pack, and JBL Synchros Bluetooth on-ear headphones.
Shelling out the extra cash upfront for a carrier-free LG V20 this holiday season may start to seem like a good idea for semi-professional and amateur software developers too after hearing of the latest bootloader unlock program expansion.
LG officially supports OS tinkering on the V20 now, but unlike the V10, G5 and G4, which are open to otherwise unauthorized ROM modifications on the old continent, the “next-gen” phablet only joins the party for the “US open market.”
We’re guessing that means US996 models sold on Amazon, B&H or Newegg as opposed to mobile operators, and of course, you should never rule out an eventual European love-spreading effort.
It’s very important to highlight LG V20 phones with unlocked bootloaders will surrender their manufacturer warranty rights, so take a moment and think about the risks before embracing a custom ROM. Remember, this thing already runs Android 7.0 Nougat, and the OEM’s proprietary skin is not that intrusive.
The post LG V20 gets official bootloader unlock support ‘for the US open market’ appeared first on Pocketnow .
